sourceDesc.bibl: Cowell, Andrew (2002): The Poetics of Arapaho Storytelling. In: Oral Tradition 17(1), 18-52. Quot. pp. 41-42.

projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly, or mediated by an interpreter, from a narrator who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose subsistence at the time of recording was, or until recently had been, depending primarily on hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative absence of external cultural influences.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the p prefix are pointers to person elements in the personography.xml file.
URIs using the q prefix are Wikidata Q identifiers and refer to the respective entries on Wikidata.
Private URIs using the g prefix are pointers to the respective lemmas in the FFDB collection of glossaries.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occurring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) on a case to case basis, without general rule.

normalization.p: Omissions as well as supplementations by the original editor are set in brackets. In all other cases, parentheses in the original are retained.
Latin passages in the original (usually to mask language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation has been removed. All other hyphenation has been retained.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. No effort was made to mark up passages in quotation marks as, for example, q, quote, said, cit, or soCalled.

body.p: White Man [traditional trickster figure] and the Ghost.
White Man was walking around [root "isee": "to go"].
They say"They say "is the translation of the narrative prefix" hee始ih-. "" Said" is the translation of "hee3eihok" and related forms. he went down along the river ["isee"].
They say he went a long way ["isee"].
They say he couldn't find any place where he could stop for the night.
They say he was still walking ["isee"] and it was already dark.
They say he saw a tepee.
They say it was light inside.
They say he went to it.
Where one enters this tepee, they say he stood there.
A person, they say he was walking around.
"I'm here," said White Man.
They say out came a woman.
"I'm tired, I'm hungry, can I stop here?" said White Man.
"I don't accept any visitors," she said.
"But you can come in and stay overnight," said this woman.
They say in went White Man.
They say he was fed.
"Where are you going?" she said.
"I'm looking for a woman to live with."
"I don't want to get married; that's why I'm always alone; you might leave me again," said this woman.
"I'll stay with you, I'll help you along," said White Man.
"If you mean it, I'll take you," said this woman.
"I mean it, I'll marry you," said White Man.
"All right, you can marry me, " said this woman.
"I want to go to sleep soon," said White Man.
They say they went to bed.
"Tell me stories, tell me about your life".
They say he told her stories, just a few.
White Man, they say he fell asleep.
They say he woke up when it was morning.
They say he looked around; a skeleton they say he saw.
They say he ran out. They say he was scared. They say he started to run.
They say some place he stopped.
They say he heard a person. They say [the person] was walking toward him.
White Man, I'm coming after you," said this woman.
White Man, they say he was scared.
They say this woman laughed.
"I fooled you," said this woman.
They say White Man came to where people lived.
That's where he slept.
They say he was watched.
That's ["nee始ees"] the way of this life.
That's ["ne始"] why people get married in the right way.
That's ["nee始ei'"] how this story ends.
